awd_titl_txt: Materials World Network:  Nanostructured Materials for High-Efficiency Solar Energy Harvesting
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
With support from the Division of Materials Research, scientists at the University of Texas at Austin (UT Austin) will collaborate with the Clausthal University of Technology (TU Clausthal) to explore materials, processing, and device technologies for high-efficiency photovoltaic devices and solar cell assemblies that can provide optimal performance under a broad range of spectral illumination conditions, as required for applications such as concentrating photovoltaics.  Concepts for materials and band-structure engineering to realize high open circuit voltages simultaneously with high photocurrent in quantum-well solar cells using GaAs/InxGa1-xAs1-ySby and GaAs/InxGa1-xAs1-y-zSbyNz heterostructures will be combined with the use of sub-wavelength-scale metal/dielectric structures for long-wavelength light trapping in thin-film semiconductor layers, enabling increased absorption in the quantum-well regions.  Epitaxial growth and basic structural and optical materials characterization at TU Clausthal will be combined with heterostructure modeling and design, materials and device processing, and optical and electrical characterization at UT Austin to develop a comprehensive understanding of epitaxial growth, material quality, optical properties, and carrier transport processes, enabling optimization of both optical absorption and photogenerated carrier collection as required to realize the very high power conversion efficiencies predicted for such devices.  In addition, "metasurface" structures based on multiple layers of metal nanostructure arrays will be designed, fabricated, and characterized at UT Austin using chemically synthesized metal nanoparticles and solution-based deposition and assembly techniques developed at TU Clausthal.  Appropriately designed, these structures will provide wavelength-selective reflectance and transmittance robust to variations in polarization and angle of incident light, and are expected to enable powerful approaches for spectral splitting of sunlight in high-efficiency solar cell assemblies.  The synthesis and fabrication approaches used will enable large-area fabrication on non-planar and flexible surfaces as required for applications such as wavelength-selective focusing of sunlight.  Photovoltaics and renewable energy concepts will be incorporated into undergraduate education at levels ranging from a required freshman introductory course to senior-level design projects at UT Austin.  

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Researchers at the University of Texas at Austin (UT Austin) will collaborate with the Clausthal University of Technology (TU Clausthal) to explore materials and manufacturing technologies for high-efficiency conversion of solar power (sunlight) to electrical power.  Emphasis will be placed on technologies that enable large-scale conversion of solar into electrical power by focusing sunlight from a large area onto a small, very efficient solar cell.  This approach will allow the use of nanoscale quantum semiconductor structures to increase the efficiency of the solar cell, and by concentrating sunlight onto a small area. it can dramatically reduce the usage of rare and expensive elements and energy-intensive manufacturing processes in solar power systems.  A strong educational component, incorporating freshman electrical engineering pedagogy and mentoring as well as early introduction to concepts for solar and renewable energy, development of senior-level design projects relevant to the proposed research, and involvement in research of undergraduates, particularly from groups traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering, will be implemented at UT Austin.  The collaboration between UT Austin and TU Clausthal will provide graduate students with direct involvement in international research activities and exposure to the increasingly international context of scientific research.

por.por_cntn:
This research project addressed materials issues pertaining to the design of solar cells that enable sunlight to be converted to electrical energy with very high efficiency over a broad range of illumination conditions (e.g., at different times of day and times of year, when the spectral, or “color”, content of sunlight can vary substantially). Inspired in part by interactions with international collaborators facilitated by this project, we also explored concepts and materials issues relevant to alternate approaches for harvesting and storing solar energy, particularly those related to realization of stable, efficient silicon-based photoelectrodes for solar-powered generation of hydrogen from water. In the first area, our focus was on design, growth, processing, and characterization of quantum-well solar cells in which multiple semiconductor materials are combined into a single electrical junction in a manner that allows for a broader range of wavelengths of light to be absorbed and generate electrical current, and for that current to be extracted at a higher voltage, and possible with only a single semiconductor material (such as silicon or gallium arsenide).  We were able to demonstrate that our approach enabled both electric current and voltage to be increased simultaneously compared to a reference device design, thereby demonstrating the viability of our proposed approach. In the second area, we conceived of and demonstrated an approach for achieving, simultaneously, good stability and efficiency in metal-insulator-semiconductor photoelectrodes for using solar energy to generate hydrogen and oxygen from water molecules. This is a key element of the so-called “hydrogen economy”, in which hydrogen produced from renewable energy sources such as sunlight can serve as a transportation fuel and an intermediary in an overall hydrogen-based energy ecosystem. The scientific challenges for efficient, stable devices for solar-powered water splitting have much in common with those for photovoltaic devices, with the added requirement that the charge carriers that are generated must drive chemical reactions in an aqueous solution, rather than simply being collected in an electric circuit. The approach we conceived and demonstrated, which involved adapting concepts from the semiconductor industry and physics of solid-state devices to the challenge of solar-powered water splitting, represents a new direction that could enable lower-cost, silicon-based photocathodes and photoanodes for the solar-powered water splitting systems.

 This program also had a large impact in education and personnel development. The collaboration with researchers in Germany funded by this project provided invaluable international experience for researchers from the U.S., and a visit by U.S. researchers to the German laboratory provided part of the inspiration for important research developments later in the program. Four graduate students were supported in part by this program, and three of them have received their Ph.D. degrees to date.  All three are actively involved in research and development at companies in the United States.  Two are at a major semiconductor electronics company, and one is at a leading company in the optical networking and communications sector.  The principal investigator for this project has also taken a very active role in advancing freshman-level electrical engineering education at the University of Texas at Austin, introducing new laboratory components, content relevant to renewable energy and nanotechnology, and extensive online content (as a complement to in-person interactions) into a freshman electrical engineering course that is currently taken by over 400 students annually. This effort has been transformative with respect to student success in this key, highly rigorous foundational course. Over a five-year period starting in 2011, overall student success rates (completing and passing the course with a grade sufficient to continue to more advanced courses) have improved from slightly over 80% to nearly 90%. For students from underrepresented minority groups, the effects have been even more dramatic. Their success rates have increased from slightly over 50% to 90%, and are now essentially identical to those of the overall student group.
